topics.body: Does anyone notice that the audio on youtube is very flat? Basically if you listen to a song on youtube abd then listen to the same song through windows media player or vlc which both have graphic equalizers, the difference is very big. Is there a real-time graphics equalizer that's software based?
topics.author: 5010fa077f123b1e4f00104e

topics.body:
"@twistedmetalero":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5374fcbc6368722589c70300#post_5374fcbc6368722589c70300
Do you even adjust the graphic equalizer in whatever program you use? As someone with a big appreciation for music, audio quality is important to me and therefor I make sure the player I use is tuned so I can listen to my music the way the artist intended. Try this: listen to a song on youtube. Now take that same song and play it with vlc and use the preset "Full Bass and Treble" under the graphic equalizer tab in the effects window. Make sure you have good quality headphones or speakers.
topics.author: 5010fa077f123b1e4f00104e

topics.body:
"@twistedmetalero":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5374ff3a6368722429b90400#post_5374ff3a6368722429b90400
No comment.

Anyway, my question still stands; is there a real-time graphics equalizer that is software based and can be used with the master sound so no matter what program it is you can adjust the quality?
topics.author: 5010fa077f123b1e4f00104e

topics.body:
"@twistedmetalero":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5374ff3a6368722429b90400#post_5374ff3a6368722429b90400
A graphic equalizer? It sure does! It also has some neat effects too like bass boost and the "wow" effect. Also VLC has an equalizer and some nice effects too. Personally for VLC I use full bass and treble, the sound is so much richer; youtube music sounds like it's coming from a paper towel tube by comparison.
topics.author: 5010fa077f123b1e4f00104e
